I have easier method: I close my fingers into fists and then open them and do it 100 times in total.

Didn't understand? Let me explain this method.
1 finger = 1

You're going to add each finger.

You're supposed to have 5 fingers in one hand which equals = 5

Now your second hand is the same so
5 x 2 = 10.

Calculate 1000 ÷ 10
It's 100.

You'll be using both hands while doing this.

When you close both of your hands into a fist and open them, you've got 10. (When your hands are first open, it doesn't count. You'll need to close your fists and reopen them to begin to count)

You don't really need much counting, cause you'll know there is 10 fingers in total in both of your hands and you'll just add your fingers up each time
OR
You can just close and reopen your hands 100 times, only counting how many times you're reopening your hands, since you already know that your fingers all of total counts as 10 and that 10 x 100 = 1000.

On one hand, the process should look like this.
🖐✊🖐✊🖐✊🖐✊🖐✊🖐✊🖐
^ ^ ^ ^ ^ ^ ^
| |-------|--------|--------|--------|--------|
| counts _ _ /_ _ _ / _ _ / _ _ _ /
Doesn't count.

Though, you'll do the same thing with both hands and many more times than. Reopening your hands 6 times was an example. Also, you don't need to be yellow to do this. Your hands can be of any color, black, white, orange, even blue if you're a smurf.

If you have more or less than 10 fingers in total if you count in all of your fingers in both of your hands, this method might not be for you...however if you do eant to try it, here are tips for you:

You may add fake replacement fingers to have 10 in total or just pretend that you have 10 fingers.
OR
If you have more, don't count the 11th finger or any higher than that. Just keep your count as 10.

Hope this was helpful.

Finger counting in binary... Since some gestures can be awkward, an alternative would be using one hand for 4 bits instead of 5. This would reduce the range to 16 on one hand and 256 on both hands, but it has the benefit that with two gestures (both hands, or two single-handed gestures) you deliver exactly one byte. It also means one gesture matches one hexadecimal digit for the transcriber.

The great thing about finger-counting is, once the process becomes automatic, you don't even need to count. You can just let your fingers go, and at any given point you can stop and know exactly how far you got.

While it doesn't use the same principle, I very much enjoy the Chisanbop finger-counting method, which I learned not too long ago. It gets you to 99, and it's very easy to learn. I use it to count seconds during 20-second screen breaks, without having to look at the screen. The tactile element (tapping) is nice, because it makes it easy to keep track of where you are without looking. It's also easy to increment rhythmically (e.g. every second), since it's like tapping a beat. I often find that I manage to get to 20 in almost exactly 20 seconds.

When I was 12 a counselor in my sleepaway summer camp taught a bunch of us kids to count like this, as a magic trick more or less. It was a typical outdoors camp, with kayaks and capture the flag and smores over the campfire. It had nothing to do with math or school. But I swear to god, that one counselor changed the path of my life, it blew my fucking mind that other ways of counting were possible. Not long after I got an interest in the rubik's cube because I saw a similarity in the way these things worked algorithmically (although I had no clue what 'algorithm' meant). Years later when It came time to choose a career, I chose CS.


A decade and a half later, here I am. I'm not a genius with this stuff, to be honest I was never even great at it to begin with. But I have a love for it, the fundamentals make me happy even though I can't grasp them instantly like some colleagues I know. But thats OK, I'm able to make do with what I've got, and I feel like that one counselor gave me a gift. I truly think that might have been the catalyzing event for the life I'm living now.


Mr. 3b1b, I'm sure you will hear it more and more as time goes on; you will be the single reason that many, many nerdy children turn into proud men with graduate degrees in their hand. I If one little blip of a memory changed my life so completely, then the countless hours of deeply engaging and profound content you put out will change many more lives, in a much deeper way. Thank you for putting so much time into your channel over the past few years.

Actually, if you're willing to do real acrobacy with your fingers, you may note that each of your fingers is made of three parts, each of which can be either open or closed. So each finger can meaningfully hold 3 bits not 1. That gives you 30 bits summing over the two hands. You can also add two bits which stem from the way you show your hands (which face). You now have 32 bits. Add to that 3 different combinations of the curvature of your wrist (straight, flexed to the inside, flexed to outside) for each of the hands.
Now you have 3^2 * 2^32 = 4 294 967 305 different states you can encode which means that you can count more than have the population on earth. Getting your hands close together or far apart will give you yet another bit. So now if you are making a concert and invite every one on Earth to watch it, you will be able to count them all on your fingers and have plenty of room still.
A bit too far fetched, but still theoretically possible. : )

Binary system

I learned this when I was a kid, and practiced it to the point where I could cycle through the numbers with either hand almost without thinking. Initially just as a novelty, but in adult life I have actually come across a lot of situations where it is really useful to be able to store 5-bit numbers physically without pen and paper:

Counting elapsed times that run over midnight (or midday if you use a 12 hour clock) by reciting the names of the hours "8 o'clock, 9 o'clock ... 2 o'clock, 3 o'clock" while counting the hours with a hand.

Recalling all the elements of a set and counting the elements that meet some criteria (like remembering who you invited to your birthday party and counting if they are vegetarian or if they don't drink alcohol).
And if you use the decimal system 1000 would be...
Really useful for those games where you have to order yourself and several other people by birthday

For everyone who wants to know what's the name of the piece playing in the background, it's Gymnopédie No.3 by Erik Satie.

Positional counting marks an important step on from tallying or one-for-one counting, since it allows us to represent the many with a few, in this case 31 with 5, or even 1003 with 10. A simpler way in which fingers might have historically come to be used in positional counting and not just tallying involves hand prints (seen on cave walls round the world). On a flat surface put a small pebble between the thumb and forefinger of a hand print, that represents 1. Move it to between the forefinger and middle finger, that's 2. Move it on to between the middle and ring finger, that's 3. And between ring and pinkie is 4. To get 5 leave the pebble where it was and put a second pebble between thumb and forefinger again. Keep on moving and adding like this, and when all four gaps between fingers are occupied, we have 10. We're relying on the fact that 1+2+3+4=10. Instead of hand prints you can use any device with 4 obvious places or spaces, and the simplest I can think of is a cross-hair grid still with us as the + sign. (A 9-space grid is still with us as #.)

As a low brass player in a symphony orchestra, I routinely need to count hundreds of bars of rests at a time.  I actually taught myself this counting method, with the variation that the pointer finger is one, middle is two, and thumb is 16 (it's a more natural movement that way).  There is the added bonus that most musical phrases are in powers of two (think of 8-bar or 16-bar phrases), so the big flips usually line up with a rehearsal mark.  No more of this "am I at 30 or 35?" malarky.

You can actually count to any number n^10-1, provided you can hold each finger in n distinct positions. For n=3, a finger down is a "0", a finger up just to the knuckle is "1", and a finger all the way up is a "2". You could count all the way up to either 59048 or RSI that way, whichever comes first.
In other news, Ronnie James Dio popularized the number 18 (or was it 306).

I think you could use your segments on four of your fingers to count higher. The first segment on your index would be one, the last would represent 3. 4 would be the first segment on your middle finger, 16 on your ring, 64 on your little finger. Tips of all fingers on one hand would be 255 and 6560 on both hands. Hooray for alternative forms of counting on your hands! A nice property is that if you want to multiply a number by two you simply cycle the fingers position to the left by one, so for exmple 7*2=14 => 111 becomes 1110.
More generally if you multiply a number by a power n of two you cycle to the left n times: 3*64=3*2^6=192 => 11 becomes 11000000.
(It's obvious, but it's nice to see it so clearly on my fingers!)

If you're an aspiring human calculator, base-3 is the optimal counting method with 2 hands. Beyond that, you need to do weird gestures or it gets very uncomfortable with your hand; ternary is already a challenge for your finger dexterity.
Including outward facing and inward facing hands, the max you will get out of 3^(2×10)-1= 3,486,784,400.
